ETYMOLOGY: From Middle English dishonour, from Anglo-Norman deshonur, deshonurer, equivalent to 'dis-' + 'honour'. (US spelling: dishonor)

MEANINGS.DEF_EN: A state of shame or disgrace; loss of honour or respect.
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: He felt great dishonour after being exposed as a fraud.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 在他被曝光为骗子后，他感到极大的耻辱。

MEANINGS.DEF_EN: To bring shame or disgrace upon (someone or something); to fail to live up to the expectations or ideals of.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 使蒙受耻辱；败坏 (名声或记忆)。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: His cowardice dishonoured his family name.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 他的懦弱玷污了他家族的声誉。

MEANINGS.DEF_EN: To refuse to accept or pay a bill of exchange, cheque, or other financial obligation when it is presented.
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: The bank will dishonour any cheque presented without sufficient funds.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 银行将拒付任何存款不足的支票。

REGISTER: Formal and general usage, frequently used in contexts involving ethics, family reputation, or finance.
